page.title: 03Ballingry: The Rise and Fall
page.content:
Until the late 19th century, there was in Ballingry parish a pastoral community of hardly more than 400 people. When mining developments began at the{MARY}and{GLENCRAIG}pits, how- ever, all that changed. Houses went up in{Glencraig, Crosshill, Lochore}and finally,{Ballingry.}By 1951, the 400 had increased to an amazing 14000! Most of these local mines had closed by the early 1960s, and now all that remains of the 'Mary', at one time the deepest mine in Scotland,is a monument in the shape of her winding gear, set on the edge of{LOCHORE MEADOWS COUNTRY {PARK,}the coal board's showpiece of land reclamation. With it went many of the miners' houses and Ballingry is now left with a population of under 10000, and a legacy of unemployment.
A.McBride.
